Maybe I could start by sharing what I've been thinking about - like how I realized I'm someone who needs preparation time, and ask him to help me understand his perspective better. Instead of "what would we do if..." maybe "help me understand why having information feels important to you" and "here's what I'm afraid of..."

I think part of what's been hard is that this feels like such a defining moment - like whatever we decide will say something fundamental about who we are as people and as parents. But maybe it's just one decision in what's going to be a lifetime of decisions we'll need to make together.

Actually, now I'm wondering if I should talk to him first before even scheduling any testing. Get on the same page about our values and how we want to approach these kinds of decisions as a team. The testing deadline isn't for a few more weeks anyway.

Thank you for helping me see this differently. I came in wanting you to tell me what to do, but I think what I really needed was to figure out how to have the right conversations. This feels like something my husband and I can work through together now, instead of me trying to solve it alone and then convince him.

<END>
